readme:
# translation-helper package for atom

This atom package helps to manage, search and update translations during development.

### Why ?

If you have larges js files with a lot of keys-values for the internationalisation (i18n) of your app, you may need this simple package in order to help you.

At Twake we use React and an observable class for i18n. Each time we need to provide translatable text we call a translation function of our i18n class with a formatted key as parameter. So we have a bunch of this in our code :

```
this.state.i18n.t("scenes.app.login.title")
```

In order to work, this i18n class use js files which contains translations for each possible keys in our code, for example in fr.js :

```
export default {
  "scenes.app.login.title": "Connectez-vous Ã  Twake"
}
```

Each time we added some new features and so some new code we had to search a place in all [some language].js files for a new key and search for its translation. Because it was fastidious, some of us just wrote sentences in english directly in code, without using our i18n service, resulting in a partially translated app and headhaches for anyone who wanted to search and find untranslatable piece of code.

This is why we made this small module to make things simpler for everyone.

### How it works

With this package, you just need to add a `this.state.i18n.t("[new key]")` in your code each time you have a new translatable text to put in your code, without worrying of which key to use.

Then any time, just press ctrl-alt-t to open translation manager, it will search for all translatable keys in your code and show you translation state, red for untranslated, green for translated.

When you updated your translations, just press save and your translation files will be updated.

### How to use

- First of all, install this package in Atom.

- Then add this comment on top of you languages files : `/* I18N_PACKAGE(fr) */`

- Configure the package with a regex used to find any translatable keys in your code

- Your ready to go !
